words.Ancient_Context: π. ἐκ τίνοσ νεώσ ποτε . . ἥκετε 'how and by what ship..?' (Euripides Tragicus Hel. 1543) | π. ἂν θάνοιμι; π. ἂν ὀλοίμην 'etc' (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 388) | π. ἂν οὖν . .  'with opt' (Aeschylus Tragicus Persius Poeta Latinus 243)
words.Target_Def: κάπως; (ειδικός σύνδεσμος) ότι

words.Modern_Examples: (τοπικά) έφτασε ως την άκρη του κόσμου || (χρονικά) θα είμαι στο σπίτι ως τις έξι || σας μιλώ ως επιστήμονας
words.Etymology_Snippet: ως < (κληρονομημένο) αρχαία ελληνική ὡς
words.Ancient_Context: τί μ' οὐκ ἔκτεινασ, ὡσ ἔδειξα μήποτε 'so that I never should' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 1392) | ὥσ μοι δέχεται κακὸν ἐκ κακοῦ αἰεί 'how constantly' (Ilias 19.290) | ὡσ οὐκ ἔστι χάρισ μετόπισθ' εὐεργέων 'how little thanks remain!' (Odyssea 22.319)

knots.Description: Nouns in -ας (Parisyllabic, Gen. Pl. Penult Stress)
knots.Nuance: Proparoxytone nouns shift stress to the penultimate syllable in Gen Pl. Paroxytone nouns maintain columnar stress. Derived mostly from Ancient Greek 3rd declension [1, 2].

knots.Description: Nouns in -ας (Parisyllabic, Gen. Pl. Final Stress)
knots.Nuance: Stress obligatorily falls on the final syllable in the Gen Plural (e.g., τουριστών). Includes nouns from AG 1st declension and newer formations [1, 2].
Paroxytone nouns shift stress to the final syllable in Gen Sg/Pl [5]. The final -ι- loses syllabic value in these forms [5, 6].
The single proparoxytone noun φίλντισι 'ivory' follows the stress shifting pattern of 2.4.3.a [6].
Forms match Masc 2.1.2. Archaic Gen Sg (-ου) often used for female referents in formal contexts (e.g., της δικαστού). Article determines natural gender [28, 29].
Forms match Masc 2.1.5. Archaic Gen Sg (-εως) often used for female referents (e.g., της πρυτάνεως). Article determines natural gender [29].
The usual suffix for forming adjectives with a passive meaning ('written', 'hated').
Forms Neuter nouns denoting a color, derived from other nouns (declines like 2.4.2).
Nouns ending in -ι in the Nominative Singular are invariably Neuter.
Forms Masculine nouns from verbs, denoting the action or result (declines like 2.1.3).
When a plural quantity NP acts as subject in a pseudopartitive, the verb normally takes plural agreement.
In formal usage, pseudopartitive constructions are often replaced by the Genitive case (e.g., τόνοι τσιμέντου).
Pseudopartitives expressing container/content can be replaced by prepositional phrases (usually με or από).
